Bought this for our son going to college. Within a year the plastic tabs on the lid broke off. They are required to operate the grinder. So, we go to order a new lid...guess what....they don't sell ANY parts for this grinder.
I have a different brand that doesn't use the plastic tabs and it has been working for 15 years. AVOID THIS ONE!
CC

reviews.reviewTitle: Long on design, short on engineering goodness
reviews.reviewText:
We take turns making coffee in the office. The first day I met this thing I opened it up and wondered "Where are the beans supposed to go?". It's small. We have to grind two batches of french roast beans to get a decent 12 pot cup brew from this thing. Having ground the first batch, I lifted the grinder and started to move it towards the filter... and it was YANKED out of my hands by the combination of the amazingly short cord and the awful exterior design. I'm sure there is a reason for the comma-shaped cross section - but my hands just do NOT fit nicely around it. I'm a big guy, but my hands just do NOT fit around this thing. Maybe it's designed for blacksmiths or Victorian Age pickpockets... but it doesn't fit in MY hands.

So, after I flung coffee grounds all over the coffee room I got to spend the next 5 minutes playing with Mr Broom and Miss Dust Buster. The next 10 minutes were spent carrying the thing to the electronics engineering department and getting the guy to extend the power cord by 2 feet.

So, what have we got ? We've got something that is hard to hold, has an abysmally short cord, and doesn't grind enough coffee for a 12 cup pot. I think it might be perfect for a trendy kitchen in a Noo Yawk flat with silver and black accessories, but it's not a robust tool for an office.

Pretty, but hard to use.

The blade broke after 14 months of use. And to take advantage of the warranty, I learned that I was required to send THEM a check for $4.00 for processing costs, not to mention the cost that I would incurr to ship it to them. It was an adequate grinder at best, so I'm definitely not going to bother returning it (I assume that this is Cuisinart's reason for having such a lame warranty in the first place). I wonder if the rest of their product line is like this. Until now, I thought Cuisinart was a name you could trust. I'm very disappointed.

This coffee grinder makes me furious on a daily basis. In order to grind enough beans to make a pot of coffee, I have to grind in two batches. IF I put enough beans in the grinder for a full pot, it INEVITABLY gets a bean stuck under the blade, then it just whirs and whirs, grinding NOTHING. This is a terrible grinder, unless you like your coffee weak. Very disappointing. A waste of money.

The lid for this grinder has a weird double wall, and coffee gets between the walls. It is very hard to clean. The only work-around we have found is to load and assemble it upside-down. Then, you can turn it over and grind without too much problem with the seal. Our old Krups never had any such problem. I also bought a Cusinart hand mixer recently, because it used to be a good brand. Both were fair to poor. Be warned.

I have an earlier model, DCG-20C, that I bought about 7 years ago in a Home Depot while it was on sale. It has served me faithfully ever since, except for 1.5 years when it was stuck in a hot attic while I was overseas - still worked well when I got home and pulled it back out! If I were a hardcore coffee gourmand, this might not be fancy enough for me, but it serves my preference for freshly-ground coffee perfectly.
Great little grinder

I bought this coffee grinder when a friend bought me whole bean coffee after I got a coffee maker. I found that it works well and grinds the perfect amount for 4 coffee cups. about 30 seconds or 40 pulses provides consistent coffee, and it has been working well for the month I've had it with no deterioration, which seems like a good sign. I would recommend this, but seeing that it's my first coffee grinder I don't have much to compare it with.
Failed after one use. Put me right off the Cuisinart brand - if they make junk, they make junk. In my experience, Krups is a reliable product.
I've used this every day for the past 14 years and it still works great. The cord twists, though. If you're brewing a whole pot of coffee you need to grind 2 batches. Highly recommend.

A powerful little sucker! I grind coffee beans, mimosa hostilis, syrian rue seeds, and oatmeal with this bad boy. It kick's serious but!
I clean it by using a damp paper towel and wipe out the inside chamber.
I accidentally dropped the lid and made a crack on it. But, it's holding up fine.
Grinder works well, but does too little at a time. Appears to be difficult to keep clean.
Had it for years and still works great. No, it doesn't grind massive quantities at a time. So what? It's efficient, powerful and easy to store due to it's small size.

qAndA.question: Does the metal part pop out to wash and pour grinds out or do you have to turn the whole piece upside down to do so?
qAndA.answer: No it does not. I was shocked by the lack of quality in this Cuisinart product. I accept that it is for small amounts. However if you fill the cup - do expect the beans to be ground up. If you put in a much smaller amount that the cup holds you might actually get all the beans ground if you press on it long enough.

qAndA.question: Received the Cuisinart DCG-12BC Grind Central Coffee Grinder as a gift. Says it does 18-cup capacity but marking on grinder cup only goes to 12-cups. What's up?
qAndA.answer: The ones that broke on me couldn't even handle two cups. The design flaw makes the beans wedge between the blade and the bottom, making the motor work overtime and catch fire. So the answer is neither. Try and return it for a better one.

qAndA.question: Can it be used to grind nuts?
qAndA.answer: The instruction booklet states to use this to only grind roasted coffee beans. It further states, "Grinding other substances, such as nuts, spices or unroasted beans may dull the blade and cause poor grinding or injury."
